content.description: Somewhat balancy moves lead up to a thin crack in the shallow dihedral.  Some face holds help you move up to a fingertip lieback crux, with good protection.  The holds quickly get larger, and easy hand jamming leads to the belay.  From here, you can rap down, or traverse left and continue to the top on Toad Warrior.
content.location: This is near the left end of the wall.  Toad Warrior goes up a prominent splitter, and finishes between two blocks on the summit.  This climb starts in the next crack to the right, in a shallow, left-facing corner.

content.description:
This two pitch adventure route is accessed from the Catapult / Arms Control anchor.

P1: From the Catapult / Arms Control anchor - Climb a cool easy crack up to a horizontal finger crack, traverse right 10 feet to reach another crack.  Negotiate a large loose block to reach an easy wide crack up to the base of the tower.  Travere right about 20 feet along the base of the tower to reach a chimney that splits the tower. (5.10a ~ 70 feet)

P2:  Chimney up to the summit passing an old but decent bolt about 35 feet up.  (5.6 ~60 feet)
content.protection: Standard rack to 3", a 4" piece can be placed but is not necessary.  There is no good way to make an anchor at the end of the first pitch in the chimney, wedge yourself in the chimney.  Bolts on top of the tower.  Rap off either west to the Tower of Cleanliness notch or east to reach the top of Natural Selection.  Bring sling or cord material to leave at the rappel anchor.
content.location: Starts from the Catapult / Arms Control anchor.

climbs.name: Sublimation
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, December 1983

content.description: Follow the crack, with a thin crux section and a fair bit of 5.8 and 5.8, for a long pitch, and belay on a huge ledge.  A short, easier but runout pitch leads to the top.  Descend by a long, tricky scramble, or find a way to rappel down.
content.location: To the left of Natural Selection is a grungy gully.  Left of this is a straight in crack - that's the route.

climbs.name: Rope Drag
climbs.fa: Dennis Yates and Roger Linfield, May 1985

content.description: A steep lieback (5.9) takes you up to the face.  A thin horizontal crack at the roof allows some gear placements.  Move down a bit to the slab and traverse 30 feet left (5.10B) until you can reach the base of a vertical crack.  A difficult entry move (5.10B) leads to moderate chimneying and hand jamming and the top.
content.protection: standard rack; include long slings to reduce the rope drag
content.location: This is on a north-facing wall just south of The Fortress.  A long but shallow roof with a slab below it marks this route.

climbs.name: Roark
climbs.fa: Roger Linfield and Dennis Yates, May 1985

content.description: Gritty, moderate jamming takes you up to the big dihedral.  The crux of the climb involves stemming up this dihedral (tiny wired nuts for protection) to where the crack widens enough for jamming.  Some jams and face moves take you up to a long hand and fist crack.  Rappel from the bolt anchor on top of The Old Man Down the Road.
content.protection: standard rack with extra tiny wired nuts
content.location: There is a broken area of the face to the right of Catapult.  This route follows a long crack system to the right of this area, with a large dihedral.

content.description: Natural Selection is a very thin crack in a small right facing corner about 30-40 yards left of Catapult.  There is a small roof halfway up.  Start a little to the right and climb easy rock to a stance 30' up.  Here, step left into the shallow corner.  There's no distinct crux, pretty fun climbing the whole way.

climbs.name: Old Man Down the Road, The

content.description: Follow the crack to the top.  The crux is a flared, shallow section in the first 15 feet.  Higher up is a 5.8 offwidth with multiple knobby face holds.  The rock is quite gritty.   There is a two bolt belay/rappel anchor at the top of the climb.
content.location: Near the right side of the wall are several vertical crack systems.  Two of the cracks are quite close together, with the left one ending near the top.  This route follows the right of those two cracks.

climbs.name: The Man Who Cried (AKA Julius Seizure)

content.description:
A great long finger and hand crack line with tons of good movement that reaches the top of the formation.  About 100 feet up, move right 5 feet to another crack until it fades out into the standard Josh run-out slab finish.  Gritty but super fun.

Two possible starts: the left crack leads to face climbing left to a bolt on fun holds to rejoin the crack (recommended) - the right start follows crack up.
content.protection:
Standard rack - doubles to 3", a 4" cam is useful but not necessary.  There is one modern protection bolt on the left start.  Gear anchor - wrap a big boulder way back at the top.

Descent: Scramble along the top east to the top of Old Man Down the Road, down climb past an old 1/4" double bolt anchor to a better double bolt anchor about 15 feet lower down.  Rappel with two 60 meter ropes.
content.location: Look for a long splitter on the right side of the Fortress, identify the left start with a bolt about 30 feet up.

content.description:
Broken cracks in the lower portion gain entry to a squeeze chimney which leads to the top.

Done as two pitches to keep the rope from getting snagged on the lower portion.
content.location:
The first crack system left of

Natural Selection

.

climbs.name: Catapult
climbs.fa: Tony Yaniro, Brett Maurer, Suzanne Sanbar

content.description:
This route is one of the best I have climbed at J-Tree. Challenging moves on solid rock for about 140' makes this  a five star classic.

Begin about 30' left of a vertical crack that does not reach the ground to gain a horizontal discontinuous seam after 10' of easy climbing. Traverse right on thin edges to a point where the seam ends about 10 feet from where the vertical crack begins. A 0 TCU protects committing face moves (5.11) to a huge horn. Turn the corner and ascend the flared, vertical crack (initially thin pro) that becomes wider and lower angle for close to 100'.

A bolted anchor with slings is used to rappel off of the route.

Double ropes work well to minimize rope drag and to rap.
content.protection: This climb requires very small cams to 3" and medium sized stoppers for protection.

content.description:
A two pitch crack route.

P1> Climb an adventurous chimney, (avoid a sprawling Datura bush in the back) to a bolted anchor on the right.  5.8 ~ 60 feet

P2> Traverse left and climb a strenuous finger to thin hand size crack.  Above follow a nice hand size crack / lieback.  Move left to the bolted anchor on Catapult.  5.11d ~70 feet
content.protection: standard trad rack to 3" - a #5 camelot would fit the crux of the P1 chimney, there is a bomber #3 camelot just below you. Bolted anchors.  Rappel or continue up Tower of Godliness to make the best 4 pitch crack route in Joshua Tree.
content.location: An obvious chimney right of Catapult leads to a stunning splitter.
